title: Thursday, 14th July, 2016

11:16 am
BE

Actually, no, not Davy. Have SocGen's FX note instead.

BE

 After reaching new historical highs, the rally in risky
assets seems to be running out of steam. Global
markets cheered the positive political outcomes in Japan
and the UK, with the re-election of Prime Minister Shinzo
Abe and the quicker-than-anticipated selection of a new
prime minister in the UK, as yields rose. Treasury yields
are back at the 1.40-1.50% level that we highlighted
before as the point where yields are at the cusp of a
pricing a paradigm shift from policy tightening to easing. In
our weekly publication we said that 10y treasury yields
have decoupled from economic fundamentals owing to a
variety of extraneous factors, and they are now currently
trading 50bp below the fair value of 1.95% (see Graph
1). We expect continued demand for Treasuries from
overseas investors, confirmed by the latest flow data that
shows Japanese investors purchased a net JPY2.55tn
of foreign debt last week, most of which was Treasuries.
This is the largest amount on record. That said, we do not
expect a paradigm shift whereby yields reach three
standard deviations from fair value, an extreme we saw
back in 2008.

BE

After a buyers’ strike at the 3y and 10y auctions earlier this
week, there was good demand at the 30y auction as the
5s30s curve bull flattened. With supply out of the way, the
market is likely to focus on retail sales and CPI on Friday.
Our economists expect retail sales ex-auto to rise 0.4%
and CPI ex-food and energy to hit 2.2% yoy. If data
continues to surprise to the upside, this could provide
There has been plenty written about the economic risks
surrounding Brexit, not least by the BoE. Thursday will be
the first solid marker on the degree to which the BoE’s
MPC (rather than just the governor) believes those risks
are a clear and present danger. The market is set up for
a 25bp cut following Governor Mark Carney’s speech
on 30 June. In this respect they are boxed in. A deferral of
the decision until the next meeting (4 August), when more
data and the Inflation Report will be available, would
create its own risks. Firstly, prior to the vote, the BoE
highlighted the probability of a recession in the event of a
Brexit. These political risks have materialised, so no policy
move would open the Bank up to accusations of either
procrastination or over-exaggerating the severity of the
situation. Secondly, equity and bond markets have been
doing well, partially driven by the assumption that the BoE
will act to stabilise the economy. A failure to do so could
have negative repercussions for risk markets as well as
bonds.

For now, bond markets remain in decent shape. Massive
supply in EGBs hardly weighed on Wednesday’s
performance as yields continued to fall in core and non-
core (moderately) on the back of fairly light news-flow. The
new 10y Bund Aug-2026 saw limited interest, with only
€4bn issued while 19% was retained by the Buba.
However, this is in line with the 18% recorded at the last
10y tap, in spite of the negative yield of -5bp this time.

11:17 am
BE

And on the cut ..............

BE

There should, in theory,
be a positive front-end reaction, as the full 25bp rate cut is
not priced. However, with the market priced for cuts in
excess of 25bp at the August meeting and beyond, there
will need to be a sense that the BoE will deliver more to
keep front-end yields moving lower. Indeed, the first four
years of the gilt curve already trade below the 25bp
threshold, which should limit the front end’s ability to rally.

BE

There is also the question of whether the BoE will restart
asset purchases. The outperformance of gilts against
swaps since the EU referendum hints that the market is
factoring in a return to gilt purchases at some stage. With
only three of the 43 economists in the Bloomberg survey
expecting this to occur at Thursday’s meeting, it is safe to
say that the market is unlikely to be looking for this to
commence imminently.

11:17 am
BE

A 25bp rate cut and more QE, in line with the view of
our UK economist, Brian Hilliard, would be an
unexpected degree of stimulus. This aggressive policy
stance could limit the ability of the 5y part of the curve
to rally, while the prospect of early asset purchases
would support the long end of the curve, in our
opinion. One reason behind Wednesday’s solid
performance was that the gilts that pay coupon on 22 July
went ex-dividend. This is the time when some funds put
cash back to work and much of this coupon will be paid to
gilts with a maturity of in excess of 15y. Add to this BoE
purchase operations, and there is significant scope for the
long end to outperform. This points to some potential for
curve flattening. However, we prefer to be long gilts
versus swaps and have suggested long 30y gilts on
asset swap and receiving 10y10y gilts (cash-for-cash
lengthening) versus paying 10y10y in swaps, as well as
a general outperformance versus Bunds.

BE

There.

PM

And Barc's summary

11:18 am
PM

UK: BoE Bank Rate decision, % (Jul, 12:00 London time) - Barclays forecast: 0.50; Consensus: 0.25; Previous: 0.50

· UK: BoE Asset Purchase Facility decision, £ bn (Jul, 12:00 London time) - Barclays forecast, Consensus & Previous: 375

· UK: MPC Bank Rate vote (Jul, 12:00 London time) - Barclays forecast: 7-2; Previous: 9-0 - As for the split of the vote, we believe that some dovish members of the Committee, such as Gertjan Vlieghe and/or Andy Haldane, could vote for a cut; consequently, we expect the split of the vote to switch from 9-0 to 7-2.

· UK: MPC Asset Purchase Facility vote (Jul, 12:00 London time) - Barclays forecast, Consensus & Previous: 9-0

· UK: MPC minutes (Jul, 12:00 London time) - As for the minutes, we expect them to highlight increased uncertainty and a substantial decline in business and household confidence post-referendum, as well as outlining the subsequent adverse impact on the UK economy. We will look for any wording that reaffirms Governor Carney’s comments on 30 June that easing over the summer is likely to be required. Ultimately, however, we believe all eyes will be on the August meeting.

11:21 am
PM

Japan: Bloomberg writes that during a meeting with Shinzo Abe's key advisor, Etsuro Honda, back in April, former Fed chief Ben Bernanke reportedly floated the idea of perpetual bonds. Bernanke reportedly warned that there was a risk Japan could return to deflation at any time and that helicopter money - or the issuance of perpetual bonds with no maturity date to be bought by the BoJ - could work as the strongest tool to overcome deflation. Bloomberg claims that Honda then asked Bernanke to meet with Abe to discuss the matter.

Advisor to Shinzo Abe, Koichi Hamada has stressed that Japan should not resort to "helicopter money". Hamada told Reuters that "There's a chance Japan will lose control of inflation ... To establish a system in Japan that allows the government to print as much money as it wants would lead to serious consequences in the future." Hamada added, "If it is just once or twice, I think it is acceptable to adopt fiscal and monetary stimulus steps simultaneously, so that they mutually reinforce each other." Hamada said it was difficult for Japan to conduct currency intervention to arrest "excessive" JPY rises, and that using monetary policy was the more "orthodox" way to address unwelcome currency appreciation.

PM

Crazy really

BE

Yen down 1% last I looked, erasing an earlier gain.

11:22 am
BE

In terms of London's movers, we have miners.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 847.30, up 35.1 (+4.32%), High: 851.20, Low: 823.50, Volume: 2.65m
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 2,533, up 72 (+2.93%), High: 2,543, Low: 2,490, Volume: 1.15m
11:23 am
BE

Couple of things around, most notably a Caz upgrade of Anglo in a push of the sector.

PM

Seems brave of them

BE

You're looking at a sector that's already doubled year to date, so yes.

11:25 am
BE

Before I share that, though, there was an admirably simple note out of Credit Suisse's APAC team last week that put the mining rally in some kind of rational context.

BE

To summarise, in a world where there's nowhere good to put your money, miners have become the least bad of the worst options.

BE

There
seems to be now a growing consensus that in the nearer term commodities may be a
decent place to park money given a US Fed that has deferred its tightening (USD no
longer rising) and with China likely to do enough economic stimulus to underpin growth at
reasonable levels.
That said, we do not see investors becoming commodity bulls. However, we do see
investors moving money back into commodity exposures with the full knowledge that once
China stimulus comes to an end, commodities will be back under pressure again. This
looks to be very much a relative call with commodities, at least temporarily, being the
lesser of evils among uncertain equity classes (e.g. financials and fully priced healthcare in
Australia).

11:26 am
BE

And, to Cazenove's Fraser Jamieson.

BE

Our expectation that base and bulk prices will fall

10% from spot is

unchanged. Yet diversified valuations still price bearish outcomes, H1’16
results are likely to be a positive catalyst for RIO, AAL & GLEN in our view,
and resilient prices have de-risked balance sheets, offering a platform for AAL
& GLEN to execute additional disposals. RIO (OW) remains our top pick,
offering attractive valuation under either spot or JPMe prices. We upgrade
AAL to OW as it appears increasingly cheap on both an absolute and relative
basis and has seen several of the crucial issues that in our view justified a
valuation discount dissipating. GLEN continues to generate best-in-class FCF
(14% spot 2017E), but this is reflected in premium multiples (6.9-7.7x spot
EV/EBITDA). BHP remains our key UW on valuation grounds, while we
expect FCF will be reduced by capex creep.

BE

 Commodity price upgrades lead to material MtM upgrades at
H1’16 results: We update forecasts for our coverage to capture JPM’s
latest commodity prices (Metals Quarterly). Higher than expected prices in
Q2 is the key driver for a +52% increase to GLEN’s FY’16E earnings,
+25% for AAL, +14% for BHP, and +13% for RIO. Of greater significance
for share prices, current commodity prices imply material upgrades to both
JPM and consensus estimates. We estimate spot 2017E EBITDA for AAL is
+35% vs BBG consensus, RIO +39%, GLEN +12%, while BHP is +9%.
 Post Brexit £/US$ translation effect boosts UK-listed target prices: UK
miners are net beneficiaries of a weaker £/US$, as cash flows and dividends
are denominated in US$. As a result, our PTs increase materially due to
converting US$ cash flows at our revised 1.37 £/US$ 2017E.

11:27 am
BE

 Valuations not stretched even on JPM’s bearish forecasts: Spot
EV/EBITDAs are attractive, in our view – RIO is on 5.4x, AAL 5.0x,
GLEN 6.8x. Under JPM’s more bearish forecasts, AAL is trading at 5.7x,
16% below its average 2013-16 multiple; GLEN is trading in-line with that
average. Since share prices already reflect downside on commodity prices,
RIO, GLEN and AAL offer attractive risk / reward, in our view.
 Anglo American – upgrade to OW (PT £10.50/sh): Our longstanding bear
thesis on AAL eventually focussed on balance sheet risk and the high
potential for new equity to be required. Recoveries in copper, PGM, coal
and diamond markets have, however, reduced those risks, with spot
ND/EBITDA set to fall less than 2x by mid-17E. We now view AAL as offering an
attractive commodity mix and strong valuation support with a spot 2017E
EV/EBITDA of 4.7x, FCF yield of 8.6%, a base case P/NPV of 0.76x being
the cheapest of the peers and a 37% SOTP discount. We also see scope for
H1 to beat consensus and the QLD Coal sale to further bolster the balance
sheet. We increase our PT to £10.50/sh (R200/sh) from £5.40/sh (R124/sh)

BE

 Rio Tinto – most preferred (OW, PT £30.00/sh): RIO combines attractive
valuation metrics on both spot and JPMe (7x EV/EBITDA on JPMe), the
highest dividend yield (3.4% in 2016e) and the safest balance sheet across the
sector in our view, offering management a significant degree of strategic
flexibility. We calculate RIO is trading at 0.83x P/NPV and raise our PT to
£30.00/sh (previously £22.50/sh).
 Glencore (N, PT £2.20/sh): Valuation is attractive following 33/17/18% YTD
price increases for zinc, nickel and coal. In Mar’16 GLEN guided to $8.1bn
2016 EBITDA, which we estimate is $9.5bn at spot. We estimate Industrial is
valued by the market at just 5.1x spot EBITDA 2017E. GLEN has best-in-
class FCF potential with a 14% spot FCF yield. We calculate GLEN is trading
at 0.80x P/NPV and we raise our PT to £2.20/sh (£1.50/sh).
 BHP – least preferred, AFL UW (PT £9.00/sh): BHP’s shares already reflect
~55% higher than spot oil prices, i.e. at spot we estimate BHP requires
more than $70bbl oil to trade at the same 2016E EV/EBITDA multiple as RIO. BHP’s
guided growth capex is just $2.0bn across 2016-17 (ex-US Onshore).
Therefore whilst BHP’s FCF is comparable to RIO’s, capex creep is likely to
mean poorer returns and debt reduction across 2016-17. We calculate BHP is
trading at 0.88x P/NPV and we raise our PT to £9.00/sh (£8.00/sh).

BE

Plus we have Morgan Stanley talking about debt loads.

11:28 am
BE

Which have come down quite a bit lately.

PM

hmm

BE

11:29 am
BE

A surprise (but welcome) development in debt markets. Since the UK
referendum, yields to maturity on 5-year debt instruments of major metals
and mining companies declined by an average of 124 bps, pushing the cost of
funding to the lowest level in nearly a year. This is in contrast to the credit
market stress - for metals & mining companies - in the latter part of 2015 and
constitutes a window of opportunity for those companies to (1) address
liquidity needs, (2) extend debt maturities, and (3) reduce funding costs by
refinancing 'expensive' debt.

BE

Buying more time. Companies with sizeable refinancing needs and liquidity
constraints, such as Nyrstar, have seized the opportunity by issuing new bonds
(see Addressing liquidity one step at a time ), which will buy more time to
execute on the mine disposal programme and set up an adequate capital
structure by replacing shorter-term credit facilities with long-term bonds. We
can draw similar conclusions for companies with 'turnaround' plans, such as
Anglo American and Glencore (in a European context).

BE

Unsurprisingly, equities of companies with highest financial leverage
would benefit the most. Against the backdrop of a solid outperformance of
metals & mining equities vs the broader market, a hypothetical scenario where
the cost of funding continues to fall is likely to favor metals & mining equities
that carry high financial leverage. Addressing liquidity needs and reducing
funding costs would reduce the market's pricing of risk (and by extension the
probability of equity stress/tail risk) and disproportionately benefit those with
high financial leverage, in our view.

11:29 am
BE

11:36 am

BE

Here's some sellside, FWIW.

11:37 am
BE

Spangel.

BE

Gulf Keystone (GKP LN – 3.25p) – Restructuring Provides Space: Today's news, while effectively wiping out existing shareholders in the short term, does provide significant relief to the balance sheet. In the longer run, however, providing the oil price recovers to a reasonable level and geopolitical situation stabilises (we believe that there is significant goodwill towards the fledgling democracy that is Kurdistan), GKP along with the other Kurdistan operators should be beneficiaries in that, which will see a recovery in the share price from these levels. Furthermore, now that the balance sheet has been cleaned up and the Company placed on a more secure footing, we believe that GKP will become an acquisition target, especially as such depressed valuations. We are placing the Company on our Watchlist, in the expectation that the share price to trade upwards from the level it settles at post the completion of the balance sheet restructuring.

BE

Cantor.

11:38 am
BE

Our view: GKP has announced today a significant, and much needed, balance sheet restructuring. Effectively, the company will undertake a debt equitisation of over US$500m of its current indebtedness (including accrued interest) in addition to an equity capital raise of between US$20m and US$25m through an open offer. This would leave GKP with a much reduced debt position of US$100m, and a sufficient capital position to continue to develop its flagship Shaikan field in Kurdistan, Iraq. Whilst there will be significant dilution to existing equity holders, we are encouraged by GKP’s approach to retaining a proportion of value for shareholders, given the extremely challenging sector environment, particularly for operators in Kurdistan. We keep our TP and recommendation Under Review whilst we update our numbers following today’s announcement.

· Significant debt reduction will improve liquidity – GKP has transformed its balance sheet following a significant debt reduction from over US$600m to US$100m through the conversion of over US$500m of existing debt into equity by way of a UK scheme of arrangement among the company, the Guaranteed Noteholders and the Convertible Bondholders. Liquidity will be boosted through an equity raise of US$20-25m, a reduction of financing costs and the removal of the US$32.5m Debt Service Reserve Account covenant. This increase in liquidity will allow GKP to continue trading and developing the Shaikan field. It is expected to allow the implementation of the company's near-term investment plan to maintain production at 40,000bopd with the potential to increase production to 55,000bopd

· Shareholder dilution and re-investment option – Current shareholders' ownership of the company will be diluted to 5%; however, shareholders will have the ability to re-invest in GKP by participating in the US$25m Open Offer for 10% of GKP's equity at closing of the restructuring.

· Pro forma capitalisation post restructuring - Upon completion of the restructuring and assuming the open offer is fully subscribed, Guaranteed Noteholders will retain US$100m of reinstated notes and will receive new common shares representing 65.5% of the equity of GKP post-closing, and convertible bondholders will receive new common shares representing 20% of the equity of GKP post-closing. Assuming the Open Offer is fully subscribed, Shareholders will own up to 14.5% of the equity of GKP post-closing.

BE

(@Frank: yes, sorry, that's right. Typing too fast to think.)

BE

And .... oh, have some Malcy too.

11:39 am
BE

So, the balance sheet restructuring has happened and pretty much as one might have expected under the circumstances. Debt will be reduced by converting $500m into equity which will amount to 5% before the equity issue. That issue, of $20-25m, underwritten mostly by Capital will be the only way that current shareholders can participate in Shaikan going forward but it should be seriously considered. While there will be a temptation to look backwards and the mess that it has become, in the future there is a world class asset in a country supported and on the mend, albeit slowly, which could be worth something. The money raised will, apparently, be enough to keep Shaikan producing at 40/- b/d and potentially 55/- b/d, not to be sneezed at, especially if you are bullish of the oil price next year. The balance sheet will be cleaned up, and the $32.5m DSRA will be removed. If it were me I would hang on in there, apply for some more stock in the likelihood of making something back and try to put the past behind me, I know that’s not easy but in the here and now GKP still has a future.

BE

And good luck to all holders.

11:47 am
PM

We recently cut SuperGroup's 2018 EPS by 14% in response to the fall in Sterling following the referendum vote. The company retains strong growth prospects which we believe offer flexibility to manage margins and have sen this with the improved leverage in the past year. Growing sales volumes driven by new space, even if LFL sales growth were to slow keeps SuperGroup on the front foot in negotiations with suppliers. On this basis we consider our recent COGS adjustments to be worst case. The shares are currently trading c20% below their pre-Brexit peak and are oversold, in our view.

PM

And Stifel

PM

Full year results are a good reflection of an innovating, increasingly well-run business, with strong top line growth, significant infrastructure improvement and good cash generation. In addition to the first FY dividend, the business will also pay a special dividend of 20.0p. Guidance should also reassure, with management forecasting gross margin accretion, despite FX pressures, and cost growth broadly in line with sales. We expect little change to consensus forecasts. We think the business will continue to benefit from a strong pace of innovation (product and store environment) and improving management and infrastructure but that this is reflected in the relatively high valuation. Hence we retain a Hold recommendation.

Here's Stifel to summarise.

BE

BTG has provided a 1Q FY17 trading update along with its AGM. Whilst trading is in line with previous guidance, weakness in sterling means the company has upgraded guidance for revenues in FY17 to £510-540m although earnings are unlikely to be impacted significantly due to hedging. We have consequently upgraded our revenue forecasts by 6% to £547m and EPS by a more modest 2% to 23p. Given the recent strong share price performance combined with little if any signs of an uptick from Varithena sales, we are downgrading our recommendation from Buy to Hold.

11:54 am
BE

BTG revises revenue guidance due to Fx. BTG has revised its revenue
guidance by 5% to £510-540m (previously £485-515m). The guidance
assumes a new Fx rate of $1.35/£. In addition, S,G&A guidance has been
revised up from £160-170m to £165-175m and R&D from £85-95m to
£90-100m. The impact on net income is expected to be modest given current
hedging.

BE

Forecasts revised to reflect Fx impact. As a result of the recent sterling
weakness we are raising our forecasts. Whilst we raise our FY17E EPS by a
modest 2%, in FY18 the impact is 4% as the current hedges dissipate.

BE

Varithena & RePneu Coil: BTG continues to make ‘steady progress’ in
establishing insurance coverage for Varithena in the US, with new physicians
also evaluating the product. Increased physician reordering and sales growth,
however, are still anticipated at some time during the current financial year.
We currently forecast £11m of sales for Varithena for FY17. For RePneu Coil,
the company cited the potential impact of the RENEW data in May 2016 on
sales of the product as a result of the patient selection criteria changing. BTG
is anticipating the completion of the rolling PMA application by the end of
2016.
Downgrade to Hold since the recent strong performance in BTG’s share price
mean the shares now trade slightly ahead of our previous target price. Based
on our revised forecasts, BTG trades at a FY17 of 31.0x, a premium to its
peers which we believe fairly reflects its strong growth prospects.

Congratulations to Calum Bennie, "Savings Expert" at Scottish Friendly, for the first canned response to the news to land in my inbox.

BE

“The decision by the Bank of England Monetary Policy Committee not to cut the base interest rate beyond its already historic low will come as scant relief for cash savers. Savers have been waiting patiently for rates to go up and as the UK economy improved all signs were that Carney and co were creeping towards an increase in the not too distant future. However, with the economic uncertainty unleashed around Brexit, all such bets are now off. The UK is on a rollercoaster of a ride for the foreseeable future.”

“Rates for cash savers are now clearly set to be in the doldrums for the long term, but with the need for people to put money aside for their and their family’s financial future as important as ever, now is the time to consider investing in shares. In particular, parents who’ve opened up a Junior ISA for their children in a cash account paying meagre rates of interest should consider if they want it to be there for up to 18 years. Transferring it to a shares investment could give greater growth potential and investing for this length of time will help ride out the ups and downs of the stock market."
